unnormalised: **Environmental News Snippet: Collaborative Effort Boosts Wildlife Conservation in Sundarbans**
normalised: **Environmental News Snippet: Collaborative Effort Boosts Wildlife Conservation in Sundarbans**

unnormalised: KOLKATA, WEST BENGAL – A joint initiative between the West Bengal Forest Department and the Wildlife Trust of India (WTI) has yielded promising results in tiger conservation within the Sundarbans National Park. Preliminary data from the 2023 tiger census indicates a marginal increase in the Royal Bengal Tiger population.
normalised: KOLKATA, WEST BENGAL – A joint initiative between the West Bengal Forest Department and the Wildlife Trust of India (W T I) has yielded promising results in tiger conservation within the Sundarbans National Park. Preliminary data from the two thousand twenty three tiger census indicates a marginal increase in the Royal Bengal Tiger population.

unnormalised: Dr. Anurag Danda, lead researcher for WTI, attributes the success to enhanced patrolling measures and community engagement programs, particularly those involving local fishermen and villagers. These programs aim to reduce human-animal conflict and curb poaching activities.
normalised: Doctor Anurag Danda, lead researcher for W T I, attributes the success to enhanced patrolling measures and community engagement programs, particularly those involving local fishermen and villagers. These programs aim to reduce human animal conflict and curb poaching activities.

unnormalised: The project has also focused on mangrove restoration, planting over 50,000 saplings across 100 acres (approx. 4,356,000 sq ft) of degraded areas. The budget allocated for this phase was Rs. 50 lakhs. Furthermore, the introduction of solar-powered fencing along the forest periphery has proven effective in minimizing livestock depredation. The next phase aims to expand the program to other critical wildlife corridors, covering an additional 200 km. The state government is also considering implementing a comprehensive eco-tourism strategy to generate revenue for conservation efforts.
normalised: The project has also focused on mangrove restoration, planting over fifty thousand saplings across one hundred acres (approximately four million three hundred and fifty six thousand square feet) of degraded areas. The budget allocated for this phase was rupee fifty lakh. Furthermore, the introduction of solar-powered fencing along the forest periphery has proven effective in minimizing livestock depredation. The next phase aims to expand the program to other critical wildlife corridors, covering an additional two hundred kilometer. The state government is also considering implementing a comprehensive eco-tourism strategy to generate revenue for conservation efforts.
